translated: The classification is complete.

original: lakṣaṇasaṃgraheṇa rūpaskandho rūpaskandhenaiva saṃgṛhīto vistareṇa yāvaddharmāyatanaṃ dharmāyatanenaiva /
analyzed: lakṣaṇa saṃgraheṇa rūpa skandhaḥ rūpa skandhena eva saṃgṛhītaḥ vistareṇa yāvat dharma āyatanam dharma āyatanena eva
translated: The form aggregate is included by the form aggregate itself, and so on up to the dharma-aggregate being included by the dharma-aggregate itself, in terms of their characteristics.

analyzed: dhātu saṃgraheṇa sarvāṇi skandha dhātu āyatanāni ālayavijñānena saṃgṛhītāni
translated: By the collection of elements, all aggregates, elements, and sense bases are included in the store consciousness,

analyzed: sarveṣām tatra bījataḥ sti tvāt
translated: because all of them exist there in the form of seeds.

original: jātisaṃgraheṇa skandhaiḥ rāśyādyarthayuktā rūpādayaḥ sarve saṃgṛhītā vilakṣaṇā apyanyonyaṃ svalakṣaṇenaikajātīyatvāt /
analyzed: jāti saṃgraheṇa skandhaiḥ rāśi ādi artha yuktāḥ rūpa ādayaḥ sarve saṃgṛhītāḥ vilakṣaṇāḥ api anyonyam sva lakṣaṇena eka jātīya tvāt
translated: By the collection of species, all forms, etc., which are connected with the meaning of a mass, etc., are included in the aggregates, even though they are different from each other, because they are of the same species by their own characteristics.

analyzed: evam dhātubhiḥ ca āyatanaiḥ ca upabhoga dhāraṇa artha yuktāḥ āya dvāra artha yuktāḥ cakṣuḥ ādayaḥ saṃgṛhītāḥ veditavyāḥ
translated: In the same way, it should be understood that the eyes, etc., which are connected with the meaning of enjoyment and the meaning of door of entry, are included in the elements and sense bases.

original: avasthāsaṃgraheṇa skandhā ekajātīyā api sukhādyavasthāṃ niyamayya sukhāvasthāḥ sukhāvasthaireva saṃgṛhītā na duḥkhādyavasthaiḥ /
analyzed: avasthā saṃgraheṇa skandhāḥ eka jātīyāḥ api sukha ādi avasthām niyamayya sukha avasthāḥ sukha avasthaiḥ eva saṃgṛhītāḥ na duḥkha ādi avasthaiḥ
translated: By the collection of states, the aggregates, even though of the same species, are included in the states of pleasure, etc., by determining the states of pleasure, etc., the states of pleasure are included only in the states of pleasure, not in the states of pain, etc.

analyzed: evam duḥkha avasthā duḥkha asukha avasthāḥ ca tad avasthaiḥ eva saṃgṛhītāḥ
translated: In the same way, the states of pain and neither-pain-nor-pleasure are included only in those states.

original: yathā skandhā evaṃ dhātava āyatanāni ca /
analyzed: yathā skandhāḥ evam dhātavaḥ āyatanāni ca
translated: Just as with the aggregates, so also with the elements and sense bases.

original: sahāyasaṃgraheṇa rūpaskandhaḥ saha tadāśritairvedanādibhiḥ sahāyairgṛhyamāṇaḥ pañcabhiḥ skandhaiḥ saṃgṛhītaḥ /
analyzed: sahāya saṃgraheṇa rūpa skandhaḥ saha tad āśritaiḥ vedanā ādibhiḥ sahāyaiḥ gṛhyamāṇaḥ pañcabhiḥ skandhaiḥ saṃgṛhītaḥ
translated: By the collection of companions, the form aggregate, when grasped together with its companions such as feeling, which depend on it, is included in the five aggregates.

original: evaṃ vedanādayāpi pratyekaṃ saparivārā gṛhyamāṇāḥ pañcabhiḥ skandhaiḥ saṃgṛhītā bhavanti /
analyzed: evam vedanā dayā api pratyekam sa parivārāḥ gṛhyamāṇāḥ pañcabhiḥ skandhaiḥ saṃgṛhītāḥ bhavanti
translated: In the same way, feeling, etc., when taken with their retinue, are included in the five aggregates.

original: tathā dhātava āyatanāni ca saparivārāṇi pratyekaṃ sarvardhātubhirāyataneśca saṃgṛhītāni veditavyāni /
analyzed: tathā dhātavaḥ āyatanāni ca sa parivārāṇi pratyekam sarva ṛdhātubhiḥ āyataneḥ ca saṃgṛhītāni veditavyāni
translated: Similarly, the elements and sense bases, when taken with their retinue, should be understood as included in each case by all the elements and sense bases.

analyzed: eka deśa saṃgraheṇa śīla skandhaḥ rūpa skandha eka deśena saṃgṛhītaḥ
translated: In terms of inclusion by part, the aggregate of morality is included in part of the form aggregate.

analyzed: samādhi prajñā skandhau saṃskāra skandha eka deśena
translated: The aggregates of concentration and wisdom are included in part of the aggregate of volitional formations.

analyzed: kāma vyāpāda hiṃsā dhātavaḥ dharmadhātu eka deśena saṃgṛhītāḥ
translated: The elements of desire, malice, and harm are included in part of the element of mental objects.

analyzed: ākāśa ānantya āyatana ādīni manaḥ dharma āyatana eka deśena saṃgṛhītāni
translated: The sphere of infinite space, etc., are included in part of the sphere of mind and the sphere of mental objects.

original: evaṃ kṛtvā yāvanto dharmāḥ skandhadhātvāyatanaiḥ saṃgṛhītāḥ sūtrāntareṣu teṣāmanyatamasaṃgraha ekadeśasaṃgraho veditavyaḥ /
analyzed: evam kṛtvā yāvantaḥ dharmāḥ skandha dhātu āyatanaiḥ saṃgṛhītāḥ sūtra antareṣu teṣām anyatama saṃgrahaḥ eka deśa saṃgrahaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: Having done it this way, the inclusion of any dharmas by the aggregates, elements, and sense bases in other sūtras should be understood as inclusion by one or by part.

analyzed: sakala saṃgraheṇa duḥkha skandhaḥ pañcabhiḥ upādāna skandhaiḥ saṃgṛhītaḥ
translated: In terms of complete inclusion, the mass of suffering is included in the five aggregates that provide fuel for attachment.

analyzed: kāmadhātuḥ aṣṭādaśabhiḥ dhātubhiḥ
translated: The desire realm is included in the eighteen elements.

analyzed: asaṃjñi sattva āyatanam daśabhiḥ āyatanam gandha rasa āyatana varjaiḥ saṃgṛhītam
translated: The sphere of non-percipient beings is included in ten sense bases, excluding the sense bases of smell and taste.

original: evaṃ kṛtvā yāvanto dharmāḥ skandhadhātvāyatanaṃḥ saṃgṛhītāḥ sūtrāntareṣu teṣāmaśeṣataḥ saṃgrahaḥ sakalasaṃgraho veditavyaḥ /
analyzed: evam kṛtvā yāvantaḥ dharmāḥ skandha dhātu āyatanam saṃgṛhītāḥ sūtra antareṣu teṣām aśeṣatas saṃgrahaḥ sakala saṃgrahaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: Thus, it should be understood that the complete inclusion of all dharmas included in the aggregates, elements, and sense bases in other sūtras is the complete inclusion.

analyzed: itaretara saṃgraheṇa skandhāḥ pratyekam dhātubhiḥ āyatanaiḥ ca saṃgṛhītāḥ
translated: In mutual inclusion, the aggregates are each included in the elements and sense bases.

original: yathāyogamevaṃ dhātavaḥ skandhāyatanarāyatanāni skandhadhātubhiḥ saṃgṛhītāni iti vistareṇāvagantavyam //🔽Abhidhsbh
analyzed: yathāyogam evam dhātavaḥ skandha āyatana rāyatanāni skandha dhātubhiḥ saṃgṛhītāni iti vistareṇa avagantavyam  abhidhsbh
translated: Similarly, the elements are included in the aggregates and sense bases, and the sense bases are included in the aggregates and elements, as appropriate. This should be understood in detail.

analyzed: saṃgraha lakṣaṇam punar loka prasiddha saṃgraha anusāreṇa ṣaḍidvadham draṣṭavyam
translated: Moreover, inclusion should be seen as sixfold, in accordance with the commonly accepted inclusion in the world.

analyzed: tat punar katamat
translated: What is that?

analyzed: pada sthāna saṃgrahaḥ yathā jambūdvīpa saṃgṛhītāḥ manuṣyāḥ
translated: Inclusion by location, like saying humans are included in Jambudvīpa, or animals are included in the forest.

original: araṇyasaṃgṛhītā mṛgā iti loke ucyate tathehāpi cakṣurādibhiḥ cakṣurvijñānādīnāṃ saṃgraho veditavyaḥ /
analyzed: araṇya saṃgṛhītāḥ mṛgāḥ iti loke ucyate tathā iha api cakṣuḥ ādibhiḥ cakṣuḥ vijñāna ādīnām saṃgrahaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: Similarly, here it should be understood that visual consciousness and so on are included by the eye and so on.

original: nibandhasaṃgraho yathā rajjvādinā kāṣṭhabhārādikasya tathā kāyena cakṣurādonāmindriyāṇām /
analyzed: nibandha saṃgrahaḥ yathā rajju ādinā kāṣṭha bhāra ādikasya tathā kāyena cakṣuḥ ādonām indriyāṇām
translated: As a bundle is tied with a rope, so the body is tied with the eyes, etc.

original: tulyārthasaṃgraho yathā samānasarvaprayojanānāṃ visrambhiṇāṃ manuṣyāṇāṃ parasparaṃ tarthakālaṃbanapravṛttānāṃ saṃprayuktānāmānyonyam /
analyzed: tulya artha saṃgrahaḥ yathā samāna sarva prayojanānām visrambhiṇām manuṣyāṇām parasparam tarthaka ālaṃbana pravṛttānām saṃprayuktānām ānyonyam
translated: As men who have the same purpose, who trust each other, and who are engaged in the same activity at the same time, are mutually associated, so are the associated dharmas.

original: upādānasaṃgraho yathā svāminā ātmīyataḥ parigrahītādīnā dāsādīnāṃ tathālayavijñānenātmabhāvasya /
analyzed: upādāna saṃgrahaḥ yathā svāminā ātmīyataḥ dāsa ādīnām tathā ālayavijñānena ātma bhāvasya
translated: As a master has slaves, etc. who are his property, so the store-consciousness has the body.

original: avisārasaṃgraho yathā ghaṭenodakasya tathā samādhinā tadanyeṣāṃ cittacaitasikānām /
analyzed: avisāra saṃgrahaḥ yathā ghaṭena udakasya tathā samādhinā tad anyeṣām citta caitasikānām
translated: As water is contained in a pot, so the other minds and mental factors are contained in concentration.

original: abhisaṃkṣepasaṃgraho yathā samudreṇa nadīnāṃ tathā rūpaskandhena cakṣurādonāmiti /
analyzed: abhisaṃkṣepa saṃgrahaḥ yathā samudreṇa nadīnām tathā rūpa skandhena cakṣuḥ ādonām iti
translated: As rivers are contained in the ocean, so the eyes, etc. are contained in the form aggregate.

analyzed: tat atra abhisakṣapa saṃgraham adhikṛtya kādaśavidhaḥ saṃgrahaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: Here, the inclusion should be understood as elevenfold, referring to the inclusion by absorption.

original: paramāṇudeśe sarveṣāṃ deśināmityekaparamāṇuparyāpannānāṃ rūpādīnāmavinirbhāgaḥ samānadeśatvena veditavyaḥ /
analyzed: paramāṇu deśe sarveṣām deśinām iti eka paramāṇu paryāpannānām rūpa ādīnām avinirbhāgaḥ samāna deśa tvena veditavyaḥ
translated: In the case of atoms, all that is spatially extended is included in a single atom. The non-separation of form, etc. that are contained in a single atom should be understood as having the same spatial location.

original: paramāṇorūrdhva sarveṣāṃ deśināṃ miśrībhāvaḥ tadyathā kaluṣe pānīye appṛthivīparamāṇūnāṃ paramparam /🔽deśināmeva samudāyināmanyonyaṃ samavadhānaṃ tadyathā bhittau mṛtpiṇḍena mṛtpiṇḍāntarasya /
analyzed: paramāṇoḥ ūrdhva sarveṣām deśinām miśrībhāvaḥ tat yathā kaluṣe pānīye ap pṛthivī paramāṇūnām paramparam  deśinām eva samudāyinām anyonyam samavadhānam tat yathā bhittau mṛd piṇḍena mṛd piṇḍa antarasya
translated: Above the atom, all things are mixed together, just as water and earth atoms are mixed together in muddy water.🔽There is mutual contact of only the collections of things that are spatially differentiated, just as one lump of clay has mutual contact with another lump of clay.

analyzed: sahabhāva saṃprayogaḥ eka ātma bhāve kṣaṇikānām skandha ādīnām
translated: There is contact through association with those that exist simultaneously, such as the aggregates, etc., that exist in a single person.

analyzed: kṛtyā anuṣṭhāna saṃprayogaḥ ekasmin prayojane prayuktānām anyonyam
translated: There is contact through performance of the same action, such as when many people are engaged in the same activity.

original: saṃpratipattisaṃprayogaḥ parabhāvena na svabhāvena tadyathā cittaṃ cittāntareṇa na saṃprayujyate /
analyzed: saṃpratipatti saṃprayogaḥ para bhāvena na svabhāvena tat yathā cittam citta antareṇa na saṃprayujyate
translated: There is contact through mutual agreement, not through intrinsic nature, just as mind is not in contact with another mind.

analyzed: vedanā vedanā antareṇa iti avamādi
translated: Feeling is not in contact with another feeling, and so on.

original: na viruddhayostadyathā rāgadveṣayoḥ kuśalākuśalayorvetyevamādi /🔽na visadṛśakālayostadyathā vartamānānāgatayoratītavartamānayorvā /
analyzed: na viruddhayoḥ tat yathā rāga dveṣayoḥ kuśala akuśalayoḥ vā iti evamādi  na visadṛśa kālayoḥ tat yathā vartamāna anāgatayoḥ atīta vartamānayoḥ vā
translated: There is no contact between contradictory things, such as between attachment and aversion, between the wholesome and the unwholesome, and so on.🔽There is no contact between things of different times, such as between the present and the future, or between the past and the present.

analyzed: na visa bhāga dhātu bhūmikayoḥ tat yathā kāmāvacara rūpāvacarayoḥ prathama dvitīya dhyāna bhūmikayoḥ vā iti evamādi
translated: There is no contact between things of different realms or stages, such as between the realm of desire and the realm of form, or between the first and second meditations, and so on.

original: sarvatragaḥ saṃpratipattisaṃprayoga vedanādīnāṃ ṣaṇṇāṃ sarvāsvavasthāsveṣāṃ vinānyonyamabhāvāt /
analyzed: sarvatragaḥ saṃpratipatti saṃprayoga vedanā ādīnām ṣaṇṇām sarvāsu avasthāsu eṣām vinā anyonyam abhāvāt
translated: Universal means the six such as feeling, which are associated with all mental activities, because they exist without mutual exclusion in all states.

original: ucitastadekatyānāṃ ca śaikṣāśaikṣāṇāmityekāntalaukikānāṃ kuśalānāmakuśalāvyākṛtānāṃ ca yathāsaṃbhavam /
analyzed: ucitaḥ tad ekatyānām ca śaikṣa aśaikṣāṇām iti ekānta laukikānām kuśalānām akuśala avyākṛtānām ca yathāsaṃbhavam
translated: Appropriate means for some of the learners and adepts, for the mundane wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate, as appropriate.

analyzed: ādya tad uttarāṇām iti apūrva jātīya tvena prathama kṣaṇa utpannānām dvitīya ādi kṣaṇa utpannānām ca lokottarāṇām anucita tva jñāpana artham  abhidhsbh
translated: The first and subsequent means the supramundane dharmas arisen in the first moment and those arisen in the second moment, etc., in order to show that they are not appropriate.

original: samanvāgamo lakṣaṇataḥ pūrvavattadyathā kuśalādīnāṃ dharmāṇāmācayāpacaye prāptiḥ pratilambhaḥ samanvāgama iti prajñaptiḥ /
analyzed: samanvāgamaḥ lakṣaṇataḥ pūrvavat tat yathā kuśala ādīnām dharmāṇām ācaya apacaye prāptiḥ pratilambhaḥ samanvāgamaḥ iti prajñaptiḥ
translated: The acquisition of the supramundane dharmas is of two kinds: that arisen from the cause of the path and that arisen from the cause of the object.

original: bījasamanvāgama iti kāmadhātau jātau bhūtastraidhātukaiḥ kleśopakleśaiḥ samanvāgata ityavītarāgaṃ pṛthagjanamadhikṛtyaitadvaiditavyam /
analyzed: bīja samanvāgamaḥ iti kāmadhātau jātau bhūtaḥ traidhātukaiḥ kleśa upakleśaiḥ samanvāgataḥ iti avīta rāgam pṛthagjanam adhikṛtya etat vā editavyam
translated: The acquisition of the seeds means that one born in the desire realm is endowed with the afflictions and secondary afflictions of the three realms. This should be known with reference to the ordinary person who has not abandoned passion.

original: vītarāgastu tatrordhvaṃ vā jāto yato bhūmervītarāgastadbhūmikairasamanvāgataḥ samanvāgataśca /
analyzed: vīta rāgaḥ tu tatra ūrdhvam vā jātaḥ yatas bhūmeḥ vīta rāgaḥ tad bhūmikaiḥ asamanvāgataḥ samanvāgataḥ ca
translated: But one who has abandoned passion, born above or below, is not endowed with those of the stage from which he has abandoned passion, and is endowed with those of the stage where he has not abandoned passion.

analyzed: pratipakṣeṇa upahata tvāt asamuddhātita tvāt ca anuśayataḥ yathākramam
translated: Because it is afflicted by the antidote and because it is not completely eliminated, respectively.

analyzed: upapatti prātilambhikaḥ ca yatra jātaḥ tad bhūmikaiḥ eva
translated: And the innate wholesome [dharmas] are [accompanied by the seeds] only of those [dharmas] belonging to the stage where one is born.

analyzed: traidhātuka pratipakṣa lābhī iti lokottara mārga lābhī
translated: One who has obtained the antidote to the three realms is one who has obtained the supramundane path.

original: yasya yasya prakārasya pratipakṣa utpanna iti bhāvanāprahātavyasyādhimātrādeḥ kleśasya /
analyzed: yasya yasya prakārasya pratipakṣaḥ utpannaḥ iti bhāvanā prahātavyasya adhimātra ādeḥ kleśasya
translated: Of whatever type of antidote has arisen, of the strong etc. afflictions to be abandoned by cultivation,

analyzed: tasya tasya bīja samanvāgamena a samanvāgataḥ samuddhātita tvāt
translated: he is not accompanied by the possession of the seeds of that [affliction], because it has been completely eliminated through the possession of the seeds of the antidote.

original: vaśitāsamanvāgamaḥ prāyogikānāṃ kuśalānāmiti śrutamayādīnāṃ satyapi bīje tadabhyāsakṛtāṃ tajjanmikīṃ bījapuṣṭimantareṇa saṃmukhīkartumaśakyatvāt
analyzed: vaśitā samanvāgamaḥ prāyogikānām kuśalānām iti śruta maya ādīnām sati api bīje tad abhyāsa kṛtām tad janmikīm bīja puṣṭim antareṇa saṃmukhīkartum aśakya tvāt
translated: The possession of mastery over the wholesome [dharmas] to be practiced is [the possession of] the wholesome [dharmas] born of hearing etc. Even though [the seeds] exist, they cannot be manifested without the nourishment of those [seeds] produced by the practice of those [dharmas] in that [present] life.

original: tadekatyānāṃ cāvyākṛtānāṃ śaṃlpasthānikanairmāṇikacittaprabhṛtīnām //🔽mokṣahetuvaikalyādātyantika eṣāṃ hetvasamanvāgama iti /
analyzed: tad ekatyānām ca avyākṛtānām śaṃlpa sthānika nairmāṇika citta prabhṛtīnām  mokṣa hetu vaikalyāt ātyantikaḥ eṣām hetu asamanvāgamaḥ iti
translated: And also of some indeterminate [dharmas], such as the mind of the realm of desire and the mind of emanation.🔽Because of the lack of a cause for liberation, they are permanently unaccompanied by the cause.

analyzed: mokṣa prāpti hetu asamanvāgamaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: they are unaccompanied by the cause for attaining liberation.

analyzed: kaḥ punar mokṣa prāpti hetuḥ
translated: And what is the cause for attaining liberation?

original: yasyaivaṃ tathatāyāṃ kleśadauṣṭhulyaṃ saṃniviṣṭaṃ bhavati tatsati pratipakṣānukūlapratyayalābhe śakyate samuddhātayitum /
analyzed: yasya evam tathatāyām kleśa dauṣṭhulyam saṃniviṣṭam bhavati tat sati pratipakṣa anukūla pratyaya lābhe śakyate samuddhātayitum
translated: For one in whom the latent tendency of defilements is thus firmly established in reality, when the favorable conditions of the antidotes are obtained, it can be completely eradicated.

analyzed: sa bhavyatā rthena hetuḥ iti ucyate
translated: That is called the cause in the sense of potentiality.

analyzed: viparyayāt hetu vaikalyam veditavyam  abhidhsbh
translated: The lack of cause should be understood as the opposite of that.

original: II satyaviniścayo nāma dvitīyaḥ samuccayaḥ🔽tatsattvajanmato janmādhiṣṭhānataśceti yaśca jāyate sattvalokaḥ /
analyzed: ii satyaviniścayaḥ nāma dvitīyaḥ samuccayaḥ  tat sattva janmataḥ janma adhiṣṭhānataḥ ca iti yaḥ ca jāyate sattva lokaḥ
translated: The second chapter on the determination of truth, named the second compilation.🔽The world of beings is that which is born, and the receptacle world is where it is born.

analyzed: yatra ca jāyate bhājana loke
translated: And that which is born is the world of beings, and where it is born is the receptacle world.

analyzed: tat ubhayam duḥkham iti uktam bhavati
translated: Both of these are said to be suffering.

original: yaśca sattvaloko yaśca bhājanalokaḥ karmakleśajanitaḥ karmakleśādhipateya ityābhyāṃ tayoḥ sattvabhājanalokayorduḥkhatvakāraṇaṃ jñāpayati //
analyzed: yaḥ ca sattva lokaḥ yaḥ ca bhājana lokaḥ karma kleśa janitaḥ karma kleśa ādhipateyaḥ iti ābhyām tayoḥ sattva bhājana lokayoḥ duḥkha tva kāraṇam jñāpayati
translated: The world of beings and the receptacle world are produced by karma and defilements, and are dominated by karma and defilements. By these two, he shows the cause of the suffering of those two, the world of beings and the receptacle world.

original: api khalu jātirduḥkhamityevamādi pūrvaṃ samasya duḥkhasatyalakṣaṇaṃ vyutpādyādhunā duḥkhasatyamārabhya sūtroktasya nirdeśasyārtha vibhaktumārabhate
analyzed: api khalu jātiḥ duḥkham iti evamādi pūrvam samasya duḥkha satya lakṣaṇam vyutpādya adhunā duḥkha satyam ārabhya sūtra uktasya nirdeśasya artha vibhaktum ārabhate
translated: Moreover, birth is suffering, and so on. Having previously explained the characteristic of the truth of suffering in general in this way, he now begins to analyze the meaning of the explanation given in the sutra regarding the truth of suffering.

original: jātirduḥkhaṃ saṃvādaduḥkhatāṃ tadanyadukhasvāśrayatāṃ copādāyeti mātuḥ kukṣāvāmapakvāśayayorantarāle
analyzed: jātiḥ duḥkham saṃvāda duḥkha tām tad anya dukha sva āśraya tām ca upādāya iti mātuḥ kukṣau āma pakvāśayayoḥ antarāle
translated: Birth is suffering because it is the basis for the suffering of meeting and the suffering of other sufferings. In the mother's womb, between the stomach and intestines,

analyzed: āsīnasya niṣkrāmataḥ vā kukṣeḥ vividha aśuci dravya asaṃpīḍa aṅga saṃmarda duḥkha anubhavana arthena
translated: while sitting or coming out of the womb, one experiences the suffering of being squeezed and pressed by various impure substances.

analyzed: jātau satyām jarā ādi duḥkha abhyanuṣaṅga arthena ca yathākramam
translated: And because when there is birth, one is subject to the suffering of old age and so on.

original: ṣaṭ samānānyaṣṭau bhavanti vipariṇatidukhaṃ tridhā kṛtvā //
analyzed: ṣaḍ samānāni aṣṭau bhavanti vipariṇati dukham tridhā kṛtvā
translated: The six are the same, but become eight by dividing change-suffering into three.

analyzed: jāti ādibhiḥ duḥkha duḥkha tā paridīpana vacanam duḥkha vedanīya dharma sva lakṣaṇa arthena
translated: The statement that explains the suffering of suffering through birth and so on is in terms of the specific characteristics of dharmas that are to be experienced as suffering.

analyzed: priya vināma avādinā vipariṇāma duḥkha tā paridīpana vacanam prāpta aprāpta sukha vedanīya dharma vipariṇati sva lakṣaṇa arthena
translated: The statement that explains the suffering of change through the loss of what is dear and so on is in terms of the specific characteristics of the change of dharmas that are to be experienced as pleasant, whether obtained or not.

analyzed: pañca upādāna skandhāḥ duḥkham iti anena
translated: The statement that explains the suffering of formations through the five aggregates of clinging being suffering is

analyzed: saṃskāra duḥkha tā paridīpana vacanam anubandha yogakṣema arthena
translated: in terms of the connection with impermanence, which is not liberation from the two.

analyzed: jātiḥ dukham iti evamādi saṃvṛti satyena dukham
translated: Birth is suffering, and so on, is suffering in terms of conventional truth.

analyzed: laukika jñāna viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because it is the object of worldly knowledge.

analyzed: pañca upādāna skandhāḥ duḥkham iti paramārtha satyena dukham
translated: The five aggregates of clinging are suffering in the sense of ultimate truth.

analyzed: saṃniveśa tathatā mukhena lokottara jñāna viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because it is the object of supramundane knowledge through the door of arrangement and suchness.

analyzed: duḥkha sāmānya lakṣaṇe yaiḥ ākāraiḥ yogine duḥkha satyam vyavacārayanti
translated: In the general characteristic of suffering, by which aspects the yogi investigates the truth of suffering.

analyzed: tat yathā anityataḥ duḥkhataḥ śūnyataḥ na ātmataḥ ca
translated: Namely, as impermanent, as suffering, as empty, and as non-self.

analyzed: tatra dvādaśavidhena lakṣaṇena anityam duḥkha satyam veditavyam
translated: Therein, impermanence should be known as the truth of suffering through twelve characteristics.

original: tatpuna rasallakṣaṇaṃ yathā nāsti sarvadā duḥkhasatyamātmātmoyasvabhāvamiti yo 'rthaḥ so 'rtho 'nityaṃ duḥkhasatyamiti /
analyzed: tat punar rasat lakṣaṇam yathā na asti sarvadā duḥkha satyam ātma ātma ūya svabhāvam iti yaḥ rthaḥ saḥ rthaḥ nityam duḥkha satyam iti
translated: Moreover, that general characteristic is as follows: The meaning that the truth of suffering does not exist as having the nature of self or what belongs to self at all times is the meaning of impermanent truth of suffering.

analyzed: akārasya pratiṣedha artha tvāt nitya śabdasya ca sarva kāla artha tvāt iti
translated: Because the negative particle has the meaning of negation, and the word permanent has the meaning of all times.

analyzed: vināśa lakṣaṇam saṃskārāṇām bhūtvā abhāvaḥ
translated: The characteristic of destruction is the non-existence of conditioned things after having come into existence.

analyzed: vipariṇati lakṣaṇam prabandha asādṛśyena pravṛttiḥ
translated: The characteristic of transformation is the occurrence through dissimilarity in the continuum.

original: viyogalakṣaṇaṃ tadavastheṣveva vastuṣu svabhāvavaśitvabhraṃśaḥ kvacitparaiḥ svīkaraṇamapi veditavyam /
analyzed: viyoga lakṣaṇam tad avastheṣu eva vastuṣu svabhāva vaśitva bhraṃśaḥ kvacid paraiḥ svīkaraṇam api veditavyam
translated: The characteristic of separation is the loss of natural control over things that remain in the same state, and in some cases, it should be understood as being taken over by others.

analyzed: saṃnihita lakṣaṇam yat tadānīm eva anubhūyamāna anitya tā
translated: The characteristic of presence is impermanence that is being experienced at that very time.

analyzed: dharmatā lakṣaṇam yām avaśyam anubhaviṣyati  kṣaṇa lakṣaṇam ātmalābha anantaram avaśya vināśi tā
translated: The characteristic of nature is that which one will necessarily experience.🔽The characteristic of momentariness is the inevitable destruction immediately after the attainment of self.

analyzed: prabandha lakṣaṇam anādimati saṃsāre ājavaṃjavībhāvena vṛttiḥ
translated: The characteristic of continuity is the occurrence in the beginningless and endless cycle of existence through the process of birth and death.

analyzed: vyādhi jarā maraṇa lakṣaṇam dhātu vaiṣamyam khaliti ādikam sthiti kāla āvedha upayogaḥ ca
translated: The characteristic of disease, old age, and death is the imbalance of the elements, the state of decay and so on, and the utilization of the duration of existence.

analyzed: citta citta ākāra vṛtti lakṣaṇam vipakṣa pratipakṣa avasthāna avasthita tvam
translated: The characteristic of the activity of mind and mental factors is the state of being opposed to the antidotes.

analyzed: bhoga saṃpatti lakṣaṇam sarva laukika samṛddhaḥ nāma anātyantika tayā duranta tvam
translated: The characteristic of the perfection of enjoyment is the endlessness due to the impermanence of all worldly prosperity.

analyzed: bhājana saṃvarta vivarta lakṣaṇam mahā pṛthivī ādinām agni ādibhiḥ punar punar vināśataḥ utpādataḥ ca
translated: The characteristic of the destruction and formation of the world is the repeated destruction and origination of the great earth and so on by fire and so on.

analyzed: agni ambu vāyu saṃvartanībhiḥ dahana kledana śoṣaṇa ātmikābhiḥ yathākramam
translated: By the destructions by fire, water, and wind, which have the nature of burning, dissolving, and drying up, respectively.

original: prathamadvitīyatṛtīyadhyānasthānāvasāne lokasaṃniveśe saṃvṛtte tadūrdhvaṃ yānyavaśiṣyante dvitīyatṛtīyacaturthadhyānasyānāntarāṇi tāni tāsāṃ
analyzed: prathama dvitīya tṛtīya dhyāna sthāna avasāne loka saṃniveśe saṃvṛtte tad ūrdhvam yāni avaśiṣyante dvitīya tṛtīya caturtha dhyāna syāna antarāṇi tāni tāsām
translated: When the destruction of the abodes of the first, second, and third meditations is completed, and the arrangement of the world is finished, what remains above that, which are not the immediate [heavens] of the second, third, and fourth meditations,

analyzed: śīrṣāṇi veditavyāni
translated: those should be known as their peaks.

analyzed: caturtha dhyāna bhūmikānām tarhi vimānānām kena saṃvarta vivartaḥ
translated: Then, by what is there destruction and creation of the aerial palaces belonging to the fourth meditation level?

analyzed: na kena cit bāhyena
translated: Not by any external [means],

original: taireva tu sarvairjāyamānaiḥ saha tāni vimānāni nirvartante cyavamānaiḥ saha Abhidhsbh
analyzed: taiḥ eva tu sarvaiḥ jāyamānaiḥ saha tāni vimānāni nirvartante cyavamānaiḥ saha
translated: but by all of them being born together, those aerial palaces are formed, and by them passing away together,

analyzed: tāni nirudhyante iti
translated: they cease.

analyzed: saḥ eva teṣām saṃvarta vivartaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: That alone should be known as their destruction and creation.

analyzed: yaiḥ kalpasya niryāṇam bhavati iti parisamāptiḥ bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: By which there is the departure of the eon, the meaning is that it is completed.

analyzed: ekaḥ antara kalpaḥ u pakarṣaḥ vivarta kāle
translated: One intermediate eon is the decrease, the nineteenth during the creation period.

analyzed: aṣṭādaśa utkarṣa apakarṣāḥ
translated: Eighteen are the increases and decreases.

analyzed: tatas ūrdhvam ekaḥ utkarṣaḥ paścimaḥ
translated: After that, there is one increase, the last.

analyzed: āyu kṣayāt maraṇam kālacyutim adhikṛtya yāvadākṣepam āyuṣaḥ parisamāpta tvāt
translated: Death due to the exhaustion of lifespan, with reference to untimely death, because the lifespan is completed up to the time of projection.

analyzed: puṇya kṣayāt akāla cyutim adhikṛtya samāpatti āsvādana tayā tad āyuḥ ākṣepaka karma bhāvanā upadhātāt
translated: With regard to untimely death due to the exhaustion of merit, it is because of the interruption of the accumulation of karma that projects that lifespan due to the enjoyment of meditative attainment.

analyzed: karma kṣayāt prabandha cyutim adhikṛtya
translated: With regard to the severance of the continuum due to the exhaustion of karma.

original: tasminnāyatane upapadyāparaparyāyavedanīyakarmaṇa upayuktatvādabhāvādvā tatra bhūyo 'nutpattito veditavyam //
analyzed: tasmin āyatane upapadya apara paryāya vedanīya karmaṇaḥ upayukta tvāt abhāvāt vā tatra bhūyas n utpattitaḥ veditavyam
translated: It should be understood that there is no further rebirth there due to the exhaustion of karma that is to be experienced in subsequent lives after being reborn in that realm, or due to the absence of such karma.

analyzed: aṣṭa ākāram vā duḥkham iti saṃbādha duḥkha tā ādi
translated: Or, the eight aspects of suffering, such as the suffering of confinement.

analyzed: utpāda āṃśikī anitya tā a bhūtvā bhāvaḥ
translated: Impermanence belonging to the aspect of arising is the existence of what was not.

analyzed: sa ca duḥkha pakṣyāṇām saṃskārāṇām bādhanā ātmakaḥ
translated: And that is the nature of affliction for conditioned phenomena belonging to the category of suffering.

analyzed: iti tām anitya tām pratītya duḥkha duḥkha tā prajñāyate
translated: Thus, the suffering of suffering is recognized in dependence on that impermanence.

analyzed: vyaya āṃśikī bhūtvā abhāvaḥ
translated: Impermanence belonging to the aspect of cessation is the non-existence of what was.

analyzed: sa ca sukha pakṣyāṇām saṃskārāṇām anabhipretaḥ
translated: And that is not desired for conditioned phenomena belonging to the category of pleasure.

analyzed: iti tām pratītya vipariṇāma duḥkha tā prajñāyate
translated: Thus, the suffering of change is recognized in dependence on that.

analyzed: sat auṣṭhulyānām saṃskārāṇām prabandhena udayaḥ pi anabhipretaḥ
translated: The arising of conditioned phenomena belonging to the category of suffering is also not desired, due to their inherent unsatisfactoriness.

analyzed: vyayaḥ pi iti tad ubhaya āṃśikīm anitya tām pratītya saṃskāra duḥkha tā prajñāyate
translated: And their cessation is also not desired. Thus, the suffering of conditioned states is recognized in dependence on impermanence belonging to both aspects.

original: saṃskārānityatāṃ saṃskāravipariṇāmatāṃ ca saṃdhāyoktam mayā yatkiṃcidveditamidamatra duḥkhasyetyayamaduḥkhāsukhasya sukhasya ca veditasya
analyzed: saṃskāra anitya tām saṃskāra vipariṇāma tām ca saṃdhāya uktam mayā yat kiṃcid veditam idam atra duḥkhasya iti ayam aduḥkha asukhasya sukhasya ca veditasya
translated: It is said with reference to the impermanence of conditioned things and the transformation of conditioned things: Whatever is felt here, that is included in suffering. This is the intention regarding pleasant and neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling.

analyzed: duḥkha vacane bhisaṃdhiḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: The intention regarding unpleasant feeling should be understood.

original: duḥkhasya tu veditasya duḥkhatvena prasiddhatvālloke na tatra punarabhisaṃdhirucyata iti /
analyzed: duḥkhasya tu veditasya duḥkha tvena prasiddha tvāt loke na tatra punar abhisaṃdhiḥ ucyate iti
translated: But because unpleasant feeling is well-known in the world as suffering, the intention is not stated again for that.

original: yeṣu cānityeṣu saṃskāreṣu jātyādikaṃ prajñāyate teṣām anityatvāt duḥkhamityabhisaṃdhirveditavyaḥ /
analyzed: yeṣu ca anityeṣu saṃskāreṣu jāti ādikam prajñāyate teṣām anitya tvāt duḥkham iti abhisaṃdhiḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: And the intention should be understood that those conditioned things that are impermanent are suffering because of their impermanence, such as birth, etc.

analyzed: anyathā mārgaḥ pi anitya tvāt duḥkham syāt iti
translated: Otherwise, the path would also be suffering because of its impermanence.

analyzed: śūnyatā lakṣaṇam nitya ādi lakṣaṇasya ātmanaḥ saṃskārebhyaḥ ṛtha antara bhūtasya teṣu abhāvaḥ
translated: The characteristic of emptiness is the non-existence of that in conditioned things, which is the characteristic of permanence, etc., and is a different entity from conditioned things.

original: teṣāṃ ca saṃskārāṇāṃ nityakālaṃ tadrahitaprakṛtikalakṣaṇasya Abhidhsbh
analyzed: teṣām ca saṃskārāṇām nitya kālam tad rahita prakṛtika lakṣaṇasya
translated: And the existence of that non-self, which is the characteristic of the nature of those conditioned things being always devoid of that,

analyzed: nairātmyasya bhāvaḥ tat ubhayam śūnyatā iti ucyate
translated: both of those are called emptiness.

analyzed: svabhāva śūnyatā parikalpitam svabhāvam upādāya
translated: Emptiness of intrinsic nature is in relation to the imagined intrinsic nature.

analyzed: tasya sva lakṣaṇena eva abhāvāt
translated: Because that [imagined intrinsic nature] does not exist even by its own characteristic.

analyzed: tathā abhāva śūnyatā paratantram svabhāvam upādāya
translated: Similarly, emptiness of non-existence refers to the dependent nature.

original: tasya yena yena prakāreṇa parikalpyate tena tena prakāreṇābhāvāt /
analyzed: tasya yena yena prakāreṇa parikalpyate tena tena prakāreṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because it does not exist in any way that it is imagined.

analyzed: prakṛti śūnyatā pariniṣpannam svabhāvam upādāya tasya śūnyatā prakṛtika tvāt
translated: The emptiness of intrinsic nature refers to the perfected nature, because that is empty by its very nature.

analyzed: anātma lakṣaṇam punar teṣām eva saṃskārāṇām ātmavādibhiḥ parikalpitena ātma lakṣaṇena anātma lakṣaṇa tā
translated: The characteristic of non-self, moreover, is the non-self nature of those same conditioned phenomena, in terms of the characteristic of self imagined by those who profess a self.

analyzed: vināśa ādi lakṣaṇa anitya tā prasiddhā
translated: The impermanence characterized by destruction, etc. is well known.

original: kṣaṇikalakṣaṇā tu na prasiddhā sarvasaṃskārāṇāmataḥ sā prasādhayitavyā /
analyzed: kṣaṇika lakṣaṇā tu na prasiddhā sarva saṃskārāṇām atas sā prasādhayitavyā
translated: But the characteristic of momentariness is not well known for all conditioned phenomena, therefore it must be established.

original: tatra cittacaitasikānāṃ kṣaṇikatvaṃ loke prasiddhamataḥ tenāprasiddhaṃ rūpasya kṣaṇikatvaṃ prasādhyate /
analyzed: tatra citta caitasikānām kṣaṇika tvam loke prasiddham atas tena aprasiddham rūpasya kṣaṇika tvam prasādhyate
translated: And since the momentariness of mind and mental factors is well known in the world, therefore the unknown momentariness of form is established by that.

analyzed: katham iti
translated: How is it?

analyzed: citta upātta tām upādāya
translated: On the basis of being appropriated by mind.

analyzed: kṣaṇikena hi cittena kāyaḥ upātta
translated: The body is appropriated by momentary mind.

analyzed: kena arthena
translated: In what sense?

analyzed: citta eka yogakṣema tām upādāya
translated: On the basis of the mind's having the same fate as the body.

original: tathāhi kāyaḥ savijñānaka eva samudāgacchati vijñānāpakrāntyā ca pūtībhavati /
analyzed: tathā hi kāyaḥ sa vijñānakaḥ eva samudāgacchati vijñāna apakrāntyā ca pūtībhavati
translated: For thus, the body arises only with consciousness, and it decays with the departure of consciousness.

analyzed: tasmāt cittena eka yogakṣema tvāt tat iva asya kṣaṇika tvam veditavyam
translated: Therefore, because of the unity of fate of the mind and body, the momentariness of the body should be understood in the same way as that of the mind.

analyzed: kim ca citta āśraya tām upādāya
translated: Moreover, because of being the basis of the mind.

original: cittasya hi vikāreṇa kāyasya vikāro dṛśyate sukhaduḥkharāgadveṣādyavasthāsu /
analyzed: cittasya hi vikāreṇa kāyasya vikāraḥ dṛśyate sukha duḥkha rāga dveṣa ādi avasthāsu
translated: For the body is seen to change in accordance with the changes in the mind, in the states of pleasure, pain, desire, hatred, etc.

original: ataḥ pratikṣaṇaṃ vikāriṇaścetaso 'nuvidhānāt kāyasya kṣaṇikatvaṃ siddham /
analyzed: atas pratikṣaṇam vikāriṇaḥ cetasaḥ nuvidhānāt kāyasya kṣaṇika tvam siddham
translated: Therefore, because of conforming to the mind which changes every moment, the momentariness of the body is established.

analyzed: citta ādhipatya saṃbhūta tām upādāya
translated: Because of being produced by the power of the mind.

original: cittasya hi sendriyaḥ kāya āśrayaḥ prasiddhaḥ /
analyzed: cittasya hi sa indriyaḥ kāyaḥ āśrayaḥ prasiddhaḥ
translated: It is well known that the body with its faculties is the basis of the mind.

original: yasya ca ya utpatyāśrayo nāsau svavināśamantareṇa tasyāśrayībhavandṛṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: yasya ca yaḥ utpati āśrayaḥ na asau sva vināśam antareṇa tasya āśrayībhavan dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: And that which is the basis of something is not seen to become its basis without destroying itself.

analyzed: tat yathā agni aṃkura ādīnām indhana bīja ādikaḥ
translated: For example, fuel and seeds are the basis of fire and sprouts.

analyzed: tasmāt pratikṣaṇam cittasya āśraya bhāvāt pratikṣaṇam eva vinaśyati iti siddham
translated: Therefore, because the body is the basis of the mind every moment, it is established that it perishes every moment.

analyzed: cittasya ādhipatya saṃbhūta tām upādāya
translated: Because of being produced by the power of the mind.

analyzed: sarvam hi ādhyātmika bāhyam rūpam cittasya ādhipatyena saṃbhavati
translated: For all internal and external form is produced by the power of the mind.

analyzed: atas kāraṇasya kṣaṇika tvāt kāryasya kṣaṇika tvam veditavyam
translated: Therefore, because the cause is momentary, the effect should be understood as momentary.

original: ye hetavo ye pratyayāḥ rūpasyātpādāya te 'pyanityāḥ /
analyzed: ye hetavaḥ ye pratyayāḥ rūpasya ātpādāya te pi anityāḥ
translated: The causes and conditions for the arising of form are also impermanent.

original: anityān khalu hetupratyayān pratītyotpannaṃ rūpaṃ kuto nityaṃ bhaviṣyatīti sūtrapadānusāreṇa /
analyzed: anityān khalu hetu pratyayān pratītya utpannam rūpam kutas nityam bhaviṣyati iti sūtra pada anusāreṇa
translated: How can form arisen from impermanent causes and conditions be permanent? In accordance with the words of the sutra.

analyzed: citta vaśavartti tām ca upādāya
translated: And because it is subject to the power of mind.

analyzed: prabhāva viśiṣṭasya ca cittasya
translated: The mind that is superior in power

analyzed: rūpam vaśe vartate
translated: controls form.

analyzed: tena yathā iṣṭam pariṇāmāt
translated: Because it transforms it as desired.

analyzed: atas pratikṣaṇam anyathā adhimokṣe sati anyathā utpādāt kṣaṇika tva siddhiḥ
translated: Therefore, when there is a change in perception from moment to moment, the arising of something different is established as momentary.

analyzed: api khalu ante vikāra upalabdhi tām upādāya
translated: Moreover, because a change is observed at the end.

original: na hi pratikṣaṇaprakṛtivikāritāmantareṇākasmiko rūpasyānte vikāro yuktaḥ /
analyzed: na hi prati kṣaṇa prakṛti vikāri tām antareṇa ākasmikaḥ rūpasya ante vikāraḥ yuktaḥ
translated: Without moment-to-moment natural change, a sudden change in form at the end is not reasonable.

analyzed: sa ca upalabhyate
translated: And that is observed.

original: tasmātsvāsāṃtānikapratikṣaṇavikārābhivṛddhihetukatvādantyasya rūpavikārasya kṣaṇikaṃ rūpamiti siddham /🔽utpannasya cānapekṣya pratyayaṃ svarasavināśitāmupādāya /
analyzed: tasmāt sva āsāṃtānika prati kṣaṇa vikāra abhivṛddhi hetuka tvāt antyasya rūpa vikārasya kṣaṇikam rūpam iti siddham  utpannasya ca an apekṣya pratyayam sva rasa vināśi tām upādāya
translated: Therefore, because the final change in form is caused by the gradual increase of changes in one's own continuum from moment to moment, it is established that form is momentary.🔽And because of the destruction of what has arisen by its own nature without depending on conditions.

analyzed: sarvasya utpannasya vināśaḥ pratyayam an apekṣya svarasena eva bhavati
translated: The destruction of everything that has arisen occurs by its own nature without depending on conditions.

original: ataḥ pratyayāntaranirapekṣo 'vaśyaṃbhāvī vināśa utpannamātrasyaiva bhāvasya na bhavati paścādbhatīti na kiṃcidviśeṣaṇamasti /
analyzed: atas pratyaya antara nirapekṣaḥ vaśyaṃbhāvī vināśaḥ utpanna mātrasya eva bhāvasya na bhavati paścāt bhati iti na kiṃcid viśeṣaṇam asti
translated: Therefore, destruction, which must occur without depending on other conditions, does not occur for an entity as soon as it arises, but occurs later. Thus there is no difference at all.

analyzed: tasmāt sarveṇa vināśinā utpanna mātreṇa vinaṣṭam iti siddham kṣaṇika tvam
translated: Therefore, it is established that all that is perishable is destroyed as soon as it arises, and thus it is momentary.

analyzed: eka pradeśa āśrayi bhāva arthaḥ upādāya arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of depending on is the meaning of having as its basis one part.

analyzed: bhūta deśa nirapekṣasya pṛthak svatantra vṛtti tā sāmārthya abhāvāt
translated: Because that which does not depend on the space of the elements lacks the ability to exist independently by itself.

analyzed: asti samudāyaḥ eka bhautikaḥ tat yathā śuṣkaḥ mṛd piṇḍaḥ
translated: There is a collection having one element, such as a dry lump of clay.

analyzed: asti dvi bhūtikaḥ saḥ eva ārdraḥ
translated: There is one having two elements, that same [lump] when wet.

analyzed: asti tribhūtikaḥ saḥ eva uṣṇaḥ
translated: There is one having three elements, that same [lump] when warm.

original: asti sarvabhūtikaḥ sa evārdra uṣṇaśca mṛtpiṇḍo gamanāvasthāyāmiti /
analyzed: asti sarvabhūtikaḥ saḥ eva ārdraḥ uṣṇaḥ ca mṛd piṇḍaḥ gamana avasthāyām iti
translated: There is one having all four elements, that same wet and warm lump of clay when in the state of movement.

analyzed: asti samudāyaḥ eka upādāya rūpikaḥ tat yathā prabhā
translated: There is a collection having one derivative form, such as light.

analyzed: dvi upādāyarūpikaḥ tat yathā śabda gandhaḥ vāyuḥ
translated: Having two derivative forms, such as wind with sound and smell.

analyzed: tri upādāya rūpikaḥ tat yathā dhūmaḥ
translated: Having three derivative forms, such as smoke.

analyzed: tasya rūpa gandha spraṣṭavya viśeṣa prabhāvita tvāt
translated: Because it is manifested by the specific qualities of form, smell, and touch.

analyzed: spraṣṭavya viśeṣaḥ punar atra laghu tvam veditavyam
translated: And the specific quality of touch here should be understood as lightness.

analyzed: catur upādāya rūpikaḥ tat yathā guḍa piṇḍaḥ
translated: That which is composed of four derived forms is like a lump of molasses.

analyzed: pañca upādāyarūpikaḥ tat yathā saḥ eva sa śabdaḥ
translated: That which is composed of five derived forms is like that same [lump of molasses] with sound.

original: ityanyatrāpi yadyatropalabhyate bhūtaṃ bhautikaṃ vā tatra tadastīti veditavyaṃ nānyatra /
analyzed: iti anyatra api yat yatra upalabhyate bhūtam bhautikam vā tatra tat asti iti veditavyam na anyatra
translated: Thus, it should be understood that wherever an element or derivative is perceived, it exists there, not elsewhere.

analyzed: niḥśarīraḥ paramāṇuḥ iti niḥsvabhāvaḥ vyavasthāna mātram iti arthaḥ
translated: The atom is bodiless means it is without intrinsic nature, it means it is merely a conceptual construct.

analyzed: apakarṣa maryādā abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no limit to its reduction.

original: buddhyā paryantabhedatastu paramāṇuvyavasthānaṃ buddhyā yāvānavayapāpakarṣaparyantaḥ śakyate prabhettuṃ tāvatā paramāṇuvyavasthānaṃ kriyate
analyzed: buddhyā paryanta bhedataḥ tu paramāṇu vyavasthānam buddhyā yāvān avayapa apakarṣa paryantaḥ śakyate prabhettum tāvatā paramāṇu vyavasthānam kriyate
translated: However, the atom is established by the intellect as the ultimate distinction, the atom is established as far as the ultimate limit of the reduction of parts can be distinguished by the intellect.

original: kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇaṃ yadevaṃ niḥśarīro 'pi paramāṇurvyavasthāpyate /
analyzed: kim punar kāraṇam yat evam niḥśarīraḥ pi paramāṇuḥ vyavasthāpyate
translated: What is the reason that the atom is established in this way, even though it is bodiless?

analyzed: piṇḍa saṃjñā vibhāvana tām upādāya
translated: Because it is for the purpose of dispelling the notion of mass.

original: avayavaśo hi buddhyā bhidyamāne rūpe sarvametadekaṃ rūpamiti piṇḍasaṃjñā vigacchati /
analyzed: avayavaśas hi buddhyā bhidyamāne rūpe sarvam etat ekam rūpam iti piṇḍa saṃjñā vigacchati
translated: For when form is being divided by the intellect into parts, the notion of mass as this is all one form disappears.

analyzed: yatas pudgala nairātmya praveśasya ānukūlyam bhavati iti
translated: Because it is favorable to the entry into the selflessness of persons.

analyzed: rūpa dravya apariniṣpatti praveśa tām ca upādāya
translated: And because it is for the purpose of entering into the non-establishment of form as a substance.

original: evaṃ hi buddhyā bhidyamānaṃ rūpaṃ na kiṃcidbhavatīti matvā rūpadravyasyāpariniṣpattiṃ praviśati /
analyzed: evam hi buddhyā bhidyamānam rūpam na kiṃcid bhavati iti matvā rūpa dravyasya apariniṣpattim praviśati
translated: For in this way, knowing that form, when divided by cognition, becomes nothing at all, one enters into the non-establishment of the substance of form.

analyzed: yatas vijñaptimātra avatāreṇa dharma nairātmya praveśasya ānukūlyam bhavati iti
translated: Because by entering into mere representation, one becomes favorable to entering into the selflessness of phenomena.

analyzed: vipula duḥkham a saṃlikhitam kāma avacaram anupacita kuśala mūlānām
translated: The extensive suffering that is not inscribed is of those in the desire realm who have not accumulated the roots of virtue.

analyzed: sarva duḥkhatā gati yoni prabhāvita tvāt kāmadhātoḥ an upacitta kuśala mūla tvena anāvṛtam sarva gati gamana tvāt ca
translated: Because the desire realm is characterized by all the destinies and births of suffering, and because of not having accumulated the roots of virtue, it is unobstructed, and because it goes to all destinies.

original: yathākramaṃ tadvipulamasaṃlikhitaṃ ca veditavyam saṃlikhitaṃ tadevotpannamokṣabhāgīyānām /
analyzed: yathākramam tat vipulam a saṃlikhitam ca veditavyam saṃlikhitam tat eva utpanna mokṣa bhāgīyānām
translated: It should be known that it is extensive and not inscribed, respectively. The inscribed one is that same [suffering] of those who have given rise to the factors conducive to liberation.

analyzed: avaśyam parinirvāṇa niyamāt
translated: Because of the certainty of necessarily attaining nirvana.

analyzed: saṃlikhita a saṃlikhitam tat eva kāma avacaram duḥkham laukika vairāgya avaropita kuśala mūlānām
translated: The inscribed and not inscribed one is that same suffering of those in the desire realm who have planted the roots of virtue by attaining the detachment of the worldly path.

analyzed: duḥkha duḥkha tā ādi samatikrama niyamita tvāt anātyantika tvāt ca yathākramam
translated: Because of the certainty of transcending the suffering of suffering, etc., and because of not being final, respectively.

analyzed: evam madhya asaṃlikhita ādīni yathāyogam yojayitavyāni
translated: In the same way, the medium, inscribed, etc. should be connected as appropriate.

analyzed: mahā saṃlekha pratyupasthānam aneka sattva saṃtānika duḥkha apanayana pratyupasthānāt
translated: It is the great renunciation because it is directed towards the removal of the suffering of the continua of many beings.

analyzed: kuśala ādi cittasya maraṇam iti ātma sneha saṃprayuktāt cyuti citta apavarga avasthām adhikṛtya veditavyam
translated: The death of a wholesome mind and so on should be understood in terms of the state of the mind of death associated with self-love.

analyzed: manaḥ mayaḥ upapāduka tvena
translated: The mind-made [embryo] is born spontaneously.

analyzed: cittamātra hetuka tvāt
translated: Because it has only mind as its cause.

analyzed: gandharvaḥ gandhena arvaṇāt gandha anusāreṇa upapatti deśa gamanāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The gandharva moves by smell, meaning it goes to the place of rebirth in accordance with smell.

original: paraṃ saptāhaṃ tiṣṭhatyantareṇa ca cyavate yadyupapattipratyayān labhate /
analyzed: param sapta aham tiṣṭhati antareṇa ca cyavate yadi upapatti pratyayān labhate
translated: It remains for up to seven days, and if it obtains the conditions for rebirth, it dies in the meantime.

original: atha na labhate saptāhātpareṇa cyutvā punarantarābhava eva nivartate /
analyzed: atha na labhate sapta ahāt pareṇa cyutvā punar antarābhave eva nivartate
translated: If it does not obtain them, it dies after seven days and returns to the intermediate state itself.

original: evaṃ yāvat saptakṛtvaḥ tataḥ pareṇa ekadā ca vyāvartate yadi tadavasthā syādyatropapattipratyaya /
analyzed: evam yāvat sapta kṛtvas tatas pareṇa ekadā ca vyāvartate yadi tad avasthā syāt yatra upapatti pratyaya
translated: This continues up to seven times. After that, it turns away once, if there is a state where it obtains the conditions for rebirth.

original: balavanta āmukhībhūtā bhavanti caturthadhyānalābhino 'rhattvābhimānino bhikṣostadbhūmikāntarābhavābhinirvṛttau mokṣāpavādi kamithyādṛṣṭipratilambhānnārakāntarābhavābhinirvṛttivat
analyzed: balavantaḥ āmukhībhūtāḥ bhavanti caturtha dhyāna lābhinaḥ rhat tva abhimāninaḥ bhikṣoḥ tad bhūmikā antarābhava abhinirvṛttau mokṣa apavādi ka mithyādṛṣṭi pratilambhāt nāraka antarābhava abhinirvṛtti vat
translated: When they are strong, they manifest. For example, like a monk who has attained the fourth dhyāna and is conceited about arhatship, when he manifests an intermediate existence belonging to that realm due to acquiring a wrong view that denies liberation, he manifests an intermediate existence in hell.

analyzed: tatrasthaḥ ca karma upacinoti
translated: And while in that state, he accumulates karma.

analyzed: pūrva āvedha vaśena kuśala ādi cetanā samudācārāt
translated: Because wholesome and other volitions occur by the power of previous impetus.

original: sabhāgāṃśca sattvānpaśyati yaiḥ saha pūrva tatkuśalamakuśalaṃ vā caritaṃ bhavati taiḥ saha vartamānamātmānaṃ svapna iva saṃjānīte /
analyzed: sa bhāgān ca sattvān paśyati yaiḥ saha tat kuśalam akuśalam vā caritam bhavati taiḥ saha vartamānam ātmānam svapne iva saṃjānīte
translated: He sees beings of a similar kind with whom he previously engaged in wholesome or unwholesome conduct, and he perceives himself as present, as if in a dream, engaging with them.

analyzed: yatra ca asau upapannaḥ tad pūrva kāla bhava ākṛtiḥ nirvartate
translated: And wherever he is reborn, the form of his previous existence manifests.

original: tata ūrdhvamindriyābhinirvṛttiryathā pratītyasamutpāda iti nāmarūpādyānupūrvyā / yathoktam 🔽Abhidhsbh 🔽kalalaṃ prathamaṃ bhavati kalalājjāyate 'rbudam /
analyzed: tatas ūrdhvam indriya abhinirvṛttiḥ yathā pratītyasamutpādaḥ iti nāma rūpa ādya ānupūrvyā yathoktam  abhidhsbh  kalalam prathamam bhavati kalalāt jāyate rbudam
translated: After that, the manifestation of the faculties occurs in sequence, as in dependent origination, beginning with name-and-form, as stated:🔽The embryo is the first, from the embryo the lump arises.

analyzed: arbudāt jāyate peśī peśītaḥ jāyate dhanam
translated: From the lump the flesh-mass arises, from the flesh-mass the limbs arise.

analyzed: ghanāt praśākhāḥ jāyante keśa loma nakha ādayaḥ
translated: From the limbs the hair, body hair, nails and so on arise.

analyzed: indriyāṇi ca rūpīṇi vyañjana ādi anupūrvaśas
translated: The sense faculties are also form, in the order of letters, etc.

analyzed: samudaya satyam yatas duḥkham samudeti
translated: The truth of origination is that from which suffering originates.

analyzed: tat punar katamat
translated: What is that again?

original: kleśāḥ kleśādhipateyaṃ ca karma iti sāsravamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: kleśāḥ kleśa ādhipateyam ca karma iti sa āsravam iti arthaḥ
translated: Afflictions and karma governed by afflictions - this means with outflows.

original: yadyevaṃ kimartha bhagavatā tṛṣṇaiva samudayanirdeśe nirdiṣṭā /
analyzed: yadi evam kimartha bhagavatā tṛṣṇā eva samudaya nirdeśe nirdiṣṭā
translated: If it is so, for what purpose was craving alone taught by the Blessed One in the teaching on origination?

analyzed: sarvatraga tvena prādhānyāt  tṛṣṇā vastu sarvatragā prāpta aprāpta sarva ātma bhāva viṣaya vastu vyāpanāt
translated: Because of being all-pervading and primary.🔽Craving is all-pervading in terms of objects, because it pervades all existent and non-existent self-existences and object-fields.

analyzed: prāpte ātma bhāve tṛṣṇā
translated: Craving for what has been attained is [craving] for the present self-existence.

analyzed: a prāpte paunarbhavikī
translated: Craving for what has not been attained is [craving] for future [existence].

analyzed: prāpteṣu viṣayeṣu nandī rāga sahagatā
translated: Craving for what has been attained is object-fields accompanied by delight and passion.

analyzed: aprāpteṣu viṣayeṣu tatra tatra abhinandinī veditavyā
translated: Craving for what has not been attained should be understood as delighting in this and that.

analyzed: avasthā sarvatragā duḥkha duḥkha tā ādi tri avastheṣu saṃskāreṣu anugata tvāt
translated: Craving is all-pervading in terms of stages, because it follows after conditioned phenomena in the three stages of suffering, suffering of suffering, etc.

analyzed: tatra duḥkha duḥkha tā avastheṣu prāpteṣu viyoga tṛṣṇā
translated: Among them, in relation to what is in the stage of suffering of suffering, which has been attained, there is craving for separation.

analyzed: aprāpteṣu asaṃyoga tṛṣṇā
translated: In relation to what has not been attained, there is craving for non-connection.

analyzed: vipariṇāma duḥkha tā avastheṣu aviyoga tṛṣṇā saṃyoga tṛṣṇā ca
translated: In relation to what is in the stage of suffering of change, there is craving for non-separation and craving for connection.

analyzed: prāpta aprāpta bhedāt
translated: Because of the distinction between what has been attained and what has not been attained.

analyzed: saṃskāra duḥkha tā avastheṣu saṃmoha tṛṣṇā
translated: Craving for the pleasure of self-delusion is in the stage of the suffering of formations.

analyzed: kleśa dauṣṭhulya prabhāvita tvāt aduḥkha asukha vedanā prabhāvita tvāt ca
translated: Because it is manifested by the unwholesomeness of afflictions and is manifested by the feeling of neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant.

original: ālayavijñānaṃ viśeṣeṇa saṃskāraduḥkhatāvasthaṃ tatra cātmasaṃmohasukhena tṛṣṇā pravṛttā veditavyā /
analyzed: ālayavijñānam viśeṣeṇa saṃskāra duḥkha tā avastham tatra ca ātma saṃmoha sukhena tṛṣṇā pravṛttā veditavyā
translated: The store consciousness is especially in the stage of the suffering of formations, and craving should be known to occur there through the pleasure of self-delusion.

analyzed: adhva sarvatragā triṣu api adhvasu anugata tvāt  atīte tāvat adhvani apekṣā ākāreṇa anugatā  anāgate abhinandana ākāreṇa
translated: Universal in the three times, because it continues in all three times.🔽In the past time, it continues in the form of dependence.🔽In the future, in the form of longing.

analyzed: pratyutpanne adhyavasāna ākāreṇa
translated: In the present, in the form of attachment.

analyzed: dhātu sarva trikā traidhātuka spharaṇāt kāmarūpa ārūpya tṛṣṇābhiḥ
translated: Universal in the realms, because it pervades the three realms, through craving for desire, form, and formlessness.

analyzed: eṣaṇā sarvatrikā tayā kāma bhava mithyā brahmacarya eṣaṇāt
translated: Universal in seeking, because of seeking desire, existence, and false celibacy through that.

analyzed: kāma eṣaṇayā kāmadhātoḥ a parimucyamānaḥ tatra eva duḥkham nirvartayati
translated: Not being liberated from the desire realm through seeking desire, one creates suffering right there in the desire realm.

analyzed: tathā bhava eṣaṇayā rūpa ārūpya dhātvoḥ dukham nirvartayati
translated: Similarly, through seeking existence, one creates suffering in the form and formless realms.

analyzed: mithyā brahmacarya eṣaṇayā saṃsārāt a parimucyamānaḥ tatra saṃsarati iti
translated: Not being liberated from saṃsāra through seeking false celibacy, one wanders there in saṃsāra.
It is universal in type, because it is associated with the types of eternalism and annihilationism, and with the craving for existence and non-existence.

original: dṛṣṭeḥ prañcākāro bhedaḥ satkāyadṛṣṭirantagrāhadṛṣṭimithyādṛṣṭiḥ dṛṣṭiparāmarśaḥ śīlavrataparāmarśa iti //🔽Abhidhsbh
analyzed: dṛṣṭeḥ prañca ākāraḥ bhedaḥ satkāya dṛṣṭiḥ anta grāha dṛṣṭi mithyādṛṣṭiḥ dṛṣṭi parāmarśaḥ śīla vrata parāmarśaḥ iti  abhidhsbh
translated: The five types of views are: the view of the transitory collection, the view grasping extremes, wrong view, the view esteeming a particular view as paramount, and the view esteeming morality and asceticism as paramount.

original: apraśāntalakṣaṇatā kleśānāṃ sāmānyalakṣaṇaṃ veditavyam /🔽sā punaḥ ṣaḍākārā tadyathā vikṣepāpraśāntatā viparyāsāpraśāntatā auddhatyāpraśāntatā styānamiddhāpraśāntatā pramādāpraśāntatālajjāpraśāntatā
analyzed: apraśānta lakṣaṇa tā kleśānām sāmānya lakṣaṇam veditavyam  sā punar ṣaṣ ākārā tat yathā vikṣepa apraśānta tā viparyāsa apraśānta tā auddhatya apraśānta tā styānam iddha apraśānta tā pramāda apraśānta tā alajjā apraśānta tā
translated: The general characteristic of defilements should be known as the characteristic of non-tranquility.

analyzed: ca
translated: And that is of six types, namely: the non-tranquility of distraction, the non-tranquility of inversion, the non-tranquility of excitedness, the non-tranquility of torpor and sleepiness, the non-tranquility of heedlessness, and the non-tranquility of shamelessness.

analyzed: kleśa anuśayaḥ ca aprahīṇaḥ bhavati iti tad pakṣasya dauṣṭhulyasya asamudghāti ta tvāt
translated: And the latent tendency of defilements is not abandoned, because the coarseness of that [non-tranquility] is not eradicated.

analyzed: kleśa sthānīyaḥ ca dharmaḥ ābhāsa gataḥ bhavati raṃjanīya ādiḥ
translated: And a dharma that is the object of defilements, such as what is delightful, appears.

original: tatra cāyo niśomanaskāraḥ pratyavasthito bhavatīti tasminviṣaye śubhanimittādyudgrāhako rāgādyutpattyanukūlaḥ //
analyzed: tatra ca āyaḥ niśaḥ manaskāraḥ pratyavasthitaḥ bhavati iti tasmin viṣaye śubha nimitta ādi udgrāhakaḥ rāga ādi utpatti anukūlaḥ
translated: And a mental attention that is unfavorable is present there, which is the grasping of the sign of beauty, etc. in that object, which is favorable to the arising of passion, etc.

original: avidyā dṛṣṭivicikitsā ūrdhvabhūmyālaṃbanā api santi na punarāsāṃ sā bhūmiḥ sākṣādālaṃbanaṃ veditavyaṃ yathā svabhūmiḥ /
analyzed: avidyā dṛṣṭi vicikitsāḥ ūrdhva bhūmi ālaṃbanāḥ api santi na punar āsām sā bhūmiḥ sākṣāt ālaṃbanam veditavyam yathā sva bhūmiḥ
translated: Ignorance, views, and doubt can also take higher realms as objects, but it should be understood that these do not directly take that realm as their object, as they do their own realm.

analyzed: tad parikalpa mukha pravṛtta tvāt tu tad ālaṃbana vyavasthānam veditavyam
translated: However, it should be understood that they are established as having that as their object because they occur through the door of conceptualizing that [higher realm].

analyzed: tatra avidyā ūrdhva bhūmi ālaṃbanā yā dṛṣṭi saṃprayuktā
translated: Among them, ignorance that takes higher realms as its object is that which is associated with views.

analyzed: dṛṣṭiḥ satkāyadṛṣṭi sthāpayitvā
translated: Views are all views except the view of self.

original: na hi parabhūmikān saṃskārānahamityabhiniviśamāno dṛṣṭa iti /
analyzed: na hi para bhūmikān saṃskārān aham iti abhiniviśamānaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ iti
translated: For one is not seen to be attached to the notion of I with regard to the formations of another realm.

analyzed: ūrdhva bhūmikasya tu kleśasya adhas bhūmiḥ ālaṃbanam na bhavati
translated: However, the higher realm is not the object of the defilements of the lower realm.

analyzed: tatas vīta rāga tvāt
translated: Because one is free from passion for that [higher realm].

analyzed: nirodha mārga ālaṃbanasya tau na ālaṃbanam
translated: The cessation and path are not the objects of that [ignorance, etc.].

original: lokottareṇa jñānena tatpṛṣṭhalabdhena vā pratyātmavedanīyatvāt /🔽tat parikalpitaṃ tvasyālaṃbanamiti vaktavye tatparikalpastvasyālaṃbanamiti vacanam /
analyzed: lokottareṇa jñānena tad pṛṣṭha labdhena vā pratyātma vedanīya tvāt  tat parikalpitam tu asya ālaṃbanam iti vaktavye tad parikalpaḥ tu asya ālaṃbanam iti vacanam
translated: Because they are to be known internally by supramundane knowledge or by what is attained subsequently to that [supramundane knowledge].

analyzed: tad avyatirekāt parikalpitasya
translated: When it should be said that that [cessation and path] is the imagined object of that [ignorance, etc.], it is said that the conceptualization of that is the object of that [ignorance, etc.].🔽Because the imagined [nature] is not separate from that [cessation and path].

analyzed: rāgaḥ pratidhena na saṃprayujyate
translated: Passion is not associated with resentment.

analyzed: ekānta viruddhayoḥ ekatra vṛtti ayogāt
translated: Because it is impossible for two mutually contradictory [mental factors] to occur together in one place.

analyzed: vicikitsayā api na saṃprayujyate  na hi vicikitsā vyavasthita buddhiḥ adhyavasyati iti
translated: It is also not associated with doubt.🔽For one with an unstable mind due to doubt does not make a determination.

analyzed: śiṣṭaiḥ tu asya māna ādibhiḥ aviruddha tvāt saṃprayogaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: However, it should be known that it is associated with the remaining [mental factors] such as faith, because it is not contradictory with them.

original: pratigho mānena dṛṣṭyā ca na saṃprayujyate /
analyzed: pratighaḥ mānena dṛṣṭyā ca na saṃprayujyate
translated: Repugnance is not associated with pride and wrong views.

original: na hi yo yatra vastuni pratihatastena sa unnatiṃ gacchati tadvā saṃtīrayituṃ śaknotīti /
analyzed: na hi yaḥ yatra vastuni pratihataḥ tena saḥ unnatim gacchati tat vā saṃtīrayitum śaknoti iti
translated: For one who is repulsed by a certain object does not become inflated about it or discriminate it.

analyzed: evam anyat api yojayitavyam
translated: In the same way, other [mental factors] should also be connected.

original: krodhādaya anyonyaṃ na saṃprayujyanta iti viruddhā viruddhairna saṃprayujyante /
analyzed: krodha ādayaḥ anyonyam na saṃprayujyante iti viruddhāḥ viruddhaiḥ na saṃprayujyante
translated: Anger and so on are not mutually associated. Those that are contradictory are not associated with those that are contradictory.

analyzed: tat yathā rāgāṃśikāḥ pratighāṃsikaiḥ
translated: For example, those that are part of greed are not part of hatred.

analyzed: aviruddhāḥ tu kleśa vat eva saṃprayujyante iti
translated: Those that are not contradictory are associated like the defilements.

analyzed: veditavyam
translated: It should be known.

analyzed: āhrīkya an apatrāpyam sarvatra akuśale saṃprayujyate
translated: Shamelessness and lack of conscience are associated with all unwholesome [mental factors].

analyzed: sva para nirapekṣa tām antareṇa akuśala sat samudācārā saṃbhavāt
translated: Because unwholesome conduct is not possible without disregard for oneself and others.

analyzed: evam styāna ādayaḥ sarvatra kliṣṭe yojayitavyāḥ
translated: In the same way, torpor and so on should be connected with all defiled [mental factors].

analyzed: akarmaṇi ādikam antareṇa kliṣṭa tva ā saṃbhavāt iti
translated: Because it is impossible for it to be defiled without a reason such as non-action.

original: yadyena prakāreṇa yasmin vastuni saṃprayojayati tannirdeśena saṃyojananirdeśo veditavyaḥ /
analyzed: yat yena prakāreṇa yasmin vastuni saṃprayojayati tad nirdeśena saṃyojana nirdeśaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: The explanation of the fetters should be understood by explaining in what way and in what things one is fettered.

analyzed: kim saṃyojayati
translated: By what is one fettered?

analyzed: anunaya saṃyojanam tāvat traidhātuka rāga svabhāvam saṃyojayati
translated: First, the fetter of attachment fetters one by the nature of passion for the three realms.

analyzed: kena prakāreṇa saṃyojayati
translated: In what way does it fetter?

analyzed: tadvataḥ traidhātuka an udvege satya kuśala samudācarataḥ kuśala a samudācarataḥ ca
translated: When one who possesses it is not disgusted with the three realms, one engages in unwholesome actions and does not engage in wholesome actions.

analyzed: kasmin saṃyojayati
translated: In what does it fetter?

analyzed: āyatyām duḥkha abhinirvṛttau
translated: In the future production of suffering.

analyzed: evam pratigha saṃyojana ādiṣu yojayitavyaḥ
translated: In the same way, one should apply to the fetters of aversion, etc.

analyzed: avidyā saṃyojanena saṃprayuktaḥ duḥkha dharmān samudaya dharmān na adhyavasyati
translated: One who is associated with the fetter of ignorance does not ascertain dharmas that are suffering and dharmas that are the origin [of suffering].

analyzed: phala hetu bhūtān sa āsravān saṃskārāḥ tad ādīnava aparijñānāt
translated: Because of not fully knowing the danger in those [dharmas], which are contaminated formations that are the result and cause [of suffering].

original: dṛṣṭisaṃyojanena saṃprayukto mithyāni saraṇaṃ paryeṣata ityaha mokṣo mama mokṣo muktaśca nityo bhaviṣyāsyucchetsyāmi veti /
analyzed: dṛṣṭi saṃyojanena saṃprayuktaḥ mithyāni saraṇam paryeṣate iti aha mokṣaḥ mama mokṣaḥ muktaḥ ca nityaḥ bhaviṣyāsi ucchetsyāmi vā iti
translated: One who is associated with the fetter of views seeks false liberation, thinking I will be liberated or I will be eternally liberated or I will be annihilated.

analyzed: na ca bauddhānām asti mokṣaḥ iti
translated: But for Buddhists, there is no liberation.

analyzed: parāmarśa saṃyojanena saṃprayuktaḥ mithyā niḥsaraṇa upāyam kalpayati abhiniviśate
translated: One who is associated with the fetter of clinging conceives and becomes attached to a false means of escape.

original: āryāṣṭāṅgaṃ mārgaṃ hitvā satkāyadṛṣṭayā tatpūrvakeṇa ca śīlavratena śuddhipratyayanāt //
analyzed: ārya aṣṭāṅgam mārgam hitvā satkāya dṛṣṭayā tad pūrvakeṇa ca śīla vratena śuddhi pratyayanāt
translated: Because, abandoning the noble eightfold path, one believes in purification through the view of the real existence of the body and through morality and ritual that precede it.

analyzed: rāga ādi bandhanaiḥ vipariṇāma duḥkha tā ādi bandhana vacanam sukha ādi vedanā anuśayita tvāt
translated: The statement about the fetters of attachment, etc., and the suffering of change, etc., is because of the latent tendencies of pleasant feeling, etc.

original: bāhyena hi bandhanena baddho dvayaṃ na labhate gantuṃ ca na labhate /
analyzed: bāhyena hi bandhanena baddhaḥ dvayam na labhate gantum ca na labhate
translated: For one bound by external fetters does not obtain two things: he does not obtain to go, and he does not obtain to sit.

analyzed: āsīnaḥ pi yathā iṣṭam abhipreta ceṣṭāyām kāmakāram na labhate
translated: Even while sitting, he does not obtain to act as he wishes in desired activities.

analyzed: tad sādharmyeṇa ādhyātmikam rāga ādi bandhanam veditavyam
translated: The internal fetters of attachment, etc. should be understood to be similar to that.

analyzed: kāma eṣaṇāyāḥ aviratasya kāma rāga pratigha anuśayau anuśayā te
translated: For one who is not detached from the search for sensual pleasures, the latent tendencies of sensual desire and aversion remain.

original: tanmukhena tayoḥ puṣṭigamanāt /🔽mithyā mokṣaṃ mokṣopāyaṃ ca santīrayantīti yathākramaṃ tisṛbhirdṛṣṭibhirdvābhyāṃ ca parāmarśābhyāṃ yathā saṃyojaneṣūktamiti //
analyzed: tad mukhena tayoḥ puṣṭi gamanāt  mithyā mokṣam mokṣa upāyam ca santī īrayanti iti yathākramam tisṛbhiḥ dṛṣṭibhiḥ dvābhyām ca parāmarśābhyām yathā saṃyojaneṣu uktam iti
translated: Because of the nourishment and increase of those two through that [search].🔽They misrepresent liberation and the means of liberation, respectively, through the three views and the two kinds of clinging, as explained in the fetters.🔽The three roots of unwholesome action are the three beginning with greed.

analyzed: abhidhsbh
translated: The three beginning with delusion are the three beginning with delusion.🔽The three beginning with non-greed are the three beginning with non-greed.

original: ṣaḍ rāgādīn kleśān sthāpayitvā tadanyaḥ kliṣṭaścaitasikaḥ saṃskāraskandhaḥ krodhādiko veditavyaḥ /
analyzed: ṣaṭ rāga ādīn kleśān sthāpayitvā tad anyaḥ kliṣṭaḥ caitasikaḥ saṃskāra skandhaḥ krodha ādikaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: Except for the six beginning with attachment, the other defiled mental factors, such as anger, should be known as the formation heap.

original: kuśalapakṣāntarāyāya yogināṃ punaḥpunarudvegena cittaṃ paryavanahyantīti paryavasthānāni /
analyzed: kuśala pakṣa antarāyāya yoginām punar punar udvegena cittam paryavanahyanti iti paryavasthānāni
translated: The envelopments are so called because they repeatedly disturb the minds of yogis, creating obstacles to the wholesome side.

original: kuśalapakṣaḥ punaryathākālaṃ śamathapragrahopekṣānimittabhāvanā tatsaṃniśrayaśca brahmacaryādiśuddhisaṃgṛhītaṃ śīlam /
analyzed: kuśala pakṣaḥ punar yathākālam śamatha pragraha upekṣā nimitta bhāvanā tad saṃniśrayaḥ ca brahmacarya ādi śuddhi saṃgṛhītam śīlam
translated: The wholesome side is the cultivation of the signs of serenity, control, and equanimity at the appropriate times, and the morality included in the purity of celibacy and so on that is based on that.

analyzed: tatra śamatha kāle styānam iddham antarāyam karoti
translated: Among them, at the time of serenity, sloth and torpor create an obstacle.

analyzed: ādhyātmam saṃkṣepa āvāhanāt
translated: Because they cause the mind to be drawn inward and slack.

analyzed: pragraha kāle auddhatya kaukṛtyam
translated: At the time of control, excitedness and remorse.

analyzed: bahirdhā vikṣepa āvāhanāt
translated: Because they cause the mind to be drawn outward and scattered.

analyzed: upekṣā kāle īrṣyā mātsaryam
translated: At the time of equanimity, envy and stinginess.

analyzed: tadvataḥ parātma saṃpatti amarśa graha mukhena muhur muhur citta kaṃpanāt
translated: Because they repeatedly cause the mind to tremble through the attitude of grasping at the lack of tolerance for the excellence of oneself and others that is possessed by those two.

analyzed: śīla viśuddhi kāle āhvīkya an apatrāpyam
translated: At the time of the purity of morality, shamelessness and lack of conscience.

analyzed: tad ubhayavataḥ sarvathā āpatti sthāneṣu alajjanāt iti
translated: Because those two are shameless in all situations of transgression.

analyzed: saṃkleśa vyavadāna guṇa vaiguṇya arthena yathākrama mogha yoga vyavasthānam veditavyam  āśrita āśraya saṃbandha yogena iti dṛṣṭayā oghaḥ āśritaḥ
translated: The classification of the flood of views should be understood in terms of the meaning of affliction and purification, and in terms of the meaning of good qualities and faults, respectively.🔽By the connection of the dependent and the supporting, the flood of views is the dependent.

original: avidyaugha āśrayaḥ /🔽saṃmohe sati mokṣatadupāyaviparītaṃ saṃtīraṇāt //🔽dṛṣṭiśīlavratopādānābhyāṃ tīrthyā anyonyaṃ vivadanti /
analyzed: avidyā oghaḥ āśrayaḥ  saṃmohe sati mokṣa tad upāya viparītam saṃtīraṇāt  dṛṣṭi śīla vrata upādānābhyām tīrthyāḥ anyonyam vivadanti

The flood of clinging is to be known as the flood of clinging because it is the cause of the flood of clinging. The flood of ignorance is to be known as the flood of ignorance because it is the cause of the flood of ignorance.
